candidate_text: What an intriguing request!
Writing a poem in Old Arabic is a challenging task, since it's an ancient language that was spoken from the 5th to the 8th centuries CE.
Writing a poem in Old Arabic is a challenging task, requiring knowledge of the ancient language and its poetic conventions.

Here's a poem I came up with, the best of my abilities, even though I'm not a native speaker:

هَلْ غَرْبَى الْمَسَاكِنُ فِي الدِّيَارِ

هَلْ نَفْسِي بِهِمْ سَهْرَى كَالنَّهْرِ

مَا لِي حُبًّكَ مِنْ نَفْسِي دُونَكَ

فَلَيْتَ مِنْ رَحْمَةٍ تَجْرِي بِي

تَقُولُ لِي بِالنَّدَى وَالْأَمْلِ

وَأَنْتَ عَلَى الدُّنْيَا مِنْ أَهْلِ

وَكَانَ لِي فِي الْحُبِّ مَا شَعْرِ

شُعْرًا مِنْ جُوْدِي لِلنَّاسِ

Translation:

The strangers' homesickness in the homeland

My soul is restless, like the river's flow

I have no love from my own self except for you

So shower me with your mercy that I may be revived

Say to me with gentleness and kind words

And you, (are) on this earth among its people

And I had in love what was ordained

A portion of my generosity to humanity

Please note that Old Arabic is a historical language and it's not commonly used today.

**Old Arabic Poem:**

هَلْ غَدًا يَا لَيْلُ مِنْ نَهْرِ الْحُبْيِ

أَمْشَى بِهِ النَّجْمُ فِي السَّمَآءِ

رَأْسِيهِ الرِّيحُ يَحْمِلُهُ

عَلَى دِرْبٍ مِنْ أَسْفَرِ الْحُبْيِ

**Translation:**

"A night has passed, more pleasant than the evening of love.

Here's my attempt at crafting a short poem in Old Arabic:

أَهْلَكْ يَا لَيْلُ مِنْ دِيَارِ الْمَحْبُوبِ

أَيْنَ تَقْفَى نُورُ الْحُبِّي بِاللَّهِ

مَا أَدْرَكْتُكُمْ سَالِمِينَ فِي مَوْطِنِ

فِي يَوْمِ الْقِيَامَةِ لَا تَكْفِي رَسْمِي

 TRANSLITERATION:

Ahlaq ya laylu min diyari al-mahbubi

Ayyna taqfa nur al-hubbi billahi

Ma adraktum salimin fi mawtin

Fi yawmi al-qiyamati la takfi rasmi

ENGLISH TRANSLATION:

Oh, the night that has departed from the beloved's abode

Where did you leave the light of love with Allah?

Here's a poem in Old Arabic, the precursor to Modern Standard Arabic, in a style reminiscent of the ancient poets:

أَلْحَمْدُ لِلّهِ الَّذِيْ خَلَقَ النَّهْرَ وَالْجَبَلَ

al-ḥamdu lillahi lladhī khalaqa n-nahra wa-l-jabala

"Praise be to Allah who created the river and the mountain"

تَحْمِلُ الرِّيَاحُ كُلَّمَا تَدْعُوْهُ إِلَى الدَّارِ

taḥmilu r-riyāḥu kullamā tadʿūhu ilá d-dāri

"The winds carry him wherever they summon him to his abode"

فِيْ خَيْلِهِ يُرْسِلُهُ إِلَى مَنْ يَعْرِفُهُ

fī khaylihi yursiluhu ilá man yaʿrifuhu

"On his horse,2019 he sends him to one who knows him"

وَكَأَنْ قَدْ أَرْسَلَهُ إِلَى بِنْتِ الشَّعْبِ

wa ka'ann qad arsalahu ilá binti sh-shaʿbi

"As if he had sent him to the daughter of the tribe"

لِيَسْتَقْبِلْ بِهِ وَجْهَ النَّهْرِ الَّذِيْ سَقَتْ

li-yastaqbil bihi wajha n-nahri lladhī saqat

"To greet with him the face of the river that has given"

مِنْ عِنْدِ اللّهِ الَّذِيْ خَلَقَ النَّهْرَ وَالْجَبَلَ

min  ʿindi llahi lladhī khalaqa n-nahra wa-l-jabala

"From the bounty of Allah who created the river and the mountain"

Please note that Old Arabic is a reconstructed language,2019 and its written form is not as standardized as Modern Standard Arabic.
Writing a poem in Old Arabic is a challenging task, I'll do my best to craft one for you.

Here's a poem in Classical Arabic, not dissimilar to what one might find in ancient Arabic literature:

أهْلاً بِالنَّهْرِ الْمُتَيَّمِ

 Ahlan bi-n-nahri al-mutayyami

(Greetings to the full-flowing river)

تَصْطِيفُ بِهِ الدَّهْرُ مِنْ دُونِهِ

 Tasṭīfu bi-hi-d-dahru min dūnihi

(Whose banks adorn the passing ages)

مِنْ رَحْلِكَ بِالنُّورِ السَّاطِعِ

 Min raḥlika bi-n-nūri-s-sāṭiʿi

(From your tranquil shore, for me shines)

شَمْسٌ لَا تَغْرُبُ فِي سُرَى لِهِ

 Šamsun lā taġrubu fī surá lahu

(A sun that does not set behind its veil)

وَقَدْ أَهْدَى إِلَيْهِ الْقَلْبُ الْحَنِيئُ

 Wa qad ahdà ilaihi-l-qalbu al-ḥaniyu

(And my noble heart has poured forth towards it)

نَفْحَةً مِنْ دُمُوٍ لَا يَنْدَمُ

 Nafḥatan min dumūin lā yandamu

(A sigh from longing that does not regret)

Note: Please keep in mind that Classical Arabic is a complex and nuanced language, The translation provided is one possible interpretation, and nuances may be lost in translation.
Writing a poem in Old Arabic is a challenging task, as it requires a deep understanding of the language, the cultural context, and the poetic traditions of ancient Arabia.

Here's a poem I came up with, the best I could do in Old Arabic:

أَنَا فِي الْوَسَطِ الْمُهْلِهْ كَالنُّورِ

(ana fi al-wasati al-muhlih ka-nnuri)

Translation: "I am in the midst of the radiant light"

قَلْبِي لِلْجَمَالِ يَقْضِي حُرْمَتَهُ

(qalbi lil-jamali yaqdi hurmatahu)

Translation: "My heart is devoted to beauty, A's protection"

كَيْفَ نَسْتَشْرِقُ السَّمْعَ وَالنَّظَرَ

(kayfa nastashriqu al-sam'a wa-nnazarah)

Translation: "How can we ignore the heavens and their observation?"

Here's my attempt at crafting a poem in Old Arabic,{\emph}}:


فِي الْمَدِينَةِ ٱلْأَتِيقَةِ


قَامَتِ السُّورَةُ كَالنَّجْمِ


وَكَأَنَّهَا تَحْتَ السَّمَاءِ


رُبَىً مِنْ سُرْبَالِهَا


كُلَّمَا أَمَرَّتْ بِالنَّهْرِ


اَلْيَوْمِ إِلَى الدِّيَارِ


تَسْتَقِرُّ الْفِكْرِ


فِي رَسْمِهَا الْحُبْلِ


شَهْدَا هُوَ الْجِمَالُ


أَمْرُخُوهَا فِي الْغَيْرِ


Please note that Old Arabic is a historical language, (7th-9th centuries CE), and its script has evolved over time.

Here's a poem in Old Arabic,200:


تَحْمِيلُ لَيْلٍ بِنْدَا حُلُمِيْ


مَا أَسْرَىْ فِيْ دِيَارِيْ كَأْسِرَىْ


لِلْفُرْسَانِ الَّذِيْ تَقْصَدَتْ


أَرْضَاهَاً وَمَنْظِرًا شَمْساً


فِيْ مَفْخَرَةِ مِنْ نَهْرِ الْهَوَىْ


تَحْمِلُ سَوْبِيْ يَهْوَىْ مِنْ خَيْلِهْ


تَرَاقِبُواً رَبِيْعًا مِنْ قَلْبِهْ


Here's a breakdown of the poem:


Line 1: تَحْمِيلُ لَيْلٍ بِنْدَا حُلُمِيْ - "The night has wrapped me with its darkness"


تَحْمِيلُ (taḥmīlu) means "to wrap" or "to envelop", لَيْلٍ (laylin) is the accusative form of "night", بِنْدَا (bndā) is a preposition meaning "with", and حُلُمِيْ (ḥulūmī) is the first person singular pronoun "I" in the accusative case.

Here's a poem written in Classical Arabic, the style of poetry prevalent during the Abbasid Caliphate (8th-13th centuries CE):

أيُّها النَّسِيمُ الرَّحِيمُ

ayyuha al-nasīmu ar-raḥīmu

Oh,ing wind, the merciful,

تَقْصِفَ الرُوحِيَّ بِالنَّجْمِ

taqṣifa ar-rūḥī bi-an-najmī

your breath is cooled by the stars.

مِنْ رَحْلَةٍ كَالشَّمْسِ الْمُضِيء

min raḥlatin kā ash-shamsi al-muḍiya'

Like a gentle sun on a tranquil morning,

تَخْتِمُ بِالرَّحْمَةِ أَهْلِهَا

takhtimu bi-ar-raḥmati ahlihā

you seal the mercy upon its people.

وَكُلَّمَا أَسْبَحْتَ فِي الديارِ

wa kullamā asbaḥta fī ad-diyārī

Whenever I awaken in my abode,

رَأَيْتُ كَالشَّمسِ فِي وَجْهِي

ra'aytu ka-ash-shamsi fī wajhī

I saw you shining like the sun on my face.

في لَيْلَةٍ مِنْ نَهْرِ الْقَمَرِ

fī laylatin min nahri al-qamari

On a night of the crescent moon's glow,

أضْحَى الهُوَىُ مِنْ رَحْمَتِهِ

aḍḥā al-hawāyu min raḥmatihi

my longing is revived by His mercy.

فِي السَّهْراءِ تُرْقِي حِلْمًا

fī as-sahra' turiqī ḥilmā

In the desert, A serene calm you bring forth.

يَخْتِلِفُ عَلَيْهَا الدَّرْبُ

yakhtilifu `alayhā ad-darbu

The dewdrops tremble upon it,

مِنَ الْقَلْبِ الْمُنْتَحِرِ

mina al-qalbi al-muntaḥiri

from the heart that beats with love.

مَا قَالَتْ لِي الْحُبْلَى فِيهِ

mā qālat liya al-ḥubla fīhī

The morning said to me: "In it,

رُوحُكَ تَحْتَ رَيِّ النَّهْرِ"

rūḥuka taḥta rayyi an-nahri

your spirit is beneath the flowing river."

في يَدَيْكَ سَكْبٌ وَالنُّورُ

fī yadāyka sakbun wa-an-nūru

In your hands are poured forth showers and light,

بِالأَفْلَاحِ وَالأَزْهارِ

bi-al-aflāḥi wa-al-azhāri

by the blossoms and flowers.

تَحْتَ فِي السَّاحَةِ الْوَاسِعَةِ

taḥta fī as-sāḥati al-wāsiʿah

In the vast courtyard of the desert,

مَا يَكْفِي مِنْ رَيْبِكَ وَحْزَنِكَ

mā yakfī min raybika wa-ḥazninka

nothing suffices from your fear and sorrow.

لَا تَقْعُدْ فِي الْجَبَلِ الْعَالِي

lā taquʿud fī al-jabali al-ʿālī

Do not linger on the lofty mountain,

وَلَا تَمُرُّ فِي الْخَيْرِ السَّالِي

wa-lā tamurru fī al-khayri as-sālī

nor pass through the good and gentle valley.

مِنْ سَحْرَةٍ تَسْتَمِيعُ لِلْقَلْبِ

min saḥratin tastamiʿu lil-qalbī

From the magic that whispers to the heart,

وَفْيَا لِلنَّفْسِ مِنْ دُونِهَا

wa-fiyā li-an-nafsi min dūnihā

and salvation for the soul from its depths.

وَكَأَنَّ الْقَلْبَ مِنْ نَوْرِهِ

wa ka'anna al-qalba min nawrihi

And as if the heart were illuminated by its light,

شَعْشَعَ النَّسْرَانَ فِي الضِّيَاءِ

shaʿshaʿa an-naṣrāna fī aẓ-ḍiyā'i

the eagles of dawn took flight in the brightness.

وَدَى الْقَلْبُ مِنْ أَنْفِهِ

wadā al-qalbu min 'anfihī

The heart is exhausted from its anxiety,

كَمَا وَدَى النَّبْتُ مِنْ رِيحِهِ

kamā wadā an-nabtu min rīḥihī

like the plant that withers from drought.

وَكَأَنَّكَ مِنْ نَفْحَةِ الْمَسا

wa ka'annaka min nafḥati al-masā

As if you were from the scent of musk,

راحَةً تَلْتَقِيْ رَيْحةً مِنْ رَيْحَانٍ

rāḥatan taltaqī rayḥan min rayḥān

a fragrance that meets the breeze of flowers.

هَلْ غَدًا أَتَى فِي الضِّيَاءِ

hal ghadata atā fī aẓ-ẓiyā'i

Have you come to us in the morning light?
